Knowledge Point: Possessive noun phrases also appear in headless\is{Noun phrase!headless} noun phrases\is{Noun phrase!headless}, in which case o/\textit{{\ꞌ}a} coalesces with the determiner to to/ta (examples (\ref{ex:5.102}–\ref{ex:5.103}) in \sectref{sec:5.6}).
Content 1: \gll Ko Koka te \ꞌīŋoa o tō\ꞌona hoi... ko Parasa \textbf{to} \textbf{te} \textbf{rū\ꞌau} era \ꞌā\ꞌana. | \gls PROM Koka ART name of POSS.3SG.O horse PROM Parasa ART:of ART old_woman DIST POSS.3SG.A | \glt ‘Koka was the name of his horse, Parasa the (name) of his old wife.’
Content 2: \gll ¿Ko ai te \ꞌīŋoa o te taŋata? ¿\textbf{To} \textbf{te} \textbf{vi\ꞌe}? | \gls ~PROM who ART name of ART name ART:of ART woman | \glt ‘What is the man’s name? And the woman’s?’

Knowledge Point: That the possessive pronoun is in determiner position, is also confirmed by the fact that prenominal quantifiers\is{Quantifier} occur after the possessor\is{Possession}, as in \REF{ex:6.4}.
Content 1: \gll ¿He aha \textbf{tō\ꞌona} rua \ꞌīŋoa? | \gls ~PRED what POSS.3SG.O two name | \glt ‘What is his second name?’

Knowledge Point: After the noun, these pronouns do have the o, as illustrated in \REF{ex:6.12} below.
Content 1: \gll He hiŋa \ꞌi tū kori haŋa rahi era \textbf{o} \textbf{rāua} he haka nininini \ꞌi ruŋa o te ma\ꞌuŋa. | \gls NTR fall at DEM play love much DIST of 3PL PRED CAUS spin:RED at above of ART mountain | \glt ‘He fell during that much-loved game of theirs, (which was) sliding down the hill.’

Knowledge Point: Finally, possessive pronouns\is{Pronoun!possessive} may occur at the end of the noun phrase, in the same position as possessive noun phrases (see (\ref{ex:6.1}–\ref{ex:6.3}) above). In this position, Ø-possessives\is{Pronoun!possessive!Ø-class} are used:
Content 1: \gll ko te vaka tama\ꞌi era \textbf{o} \textbf{te} \textbf{\ꞌariki} | \gls PROM ART canoe fight DIST of ART king | \glt ‘the battle canoe of the king’
Content 2: \gll mai tū \ꞌōpata nei \ꞌā \textbf{o} \textbf{te} \textbf{karikari} | \gls from DEM cliff PROX IDENT of ART narrow_part | \glt ‘from this same cliff of the narrow rock’

Knowledge Point: There is an important difference though: while in \REF{ex:6.25} \textit{to te rū{\ꞌ}au} has a straightforward possessive sense (parallel to the possessive phrase \textit{o tō{\ꞌ}ona hoi}), in (\ref{ex:6.23}–\ref{ex:6.24}) the possessive phrase occurs in a context where normally the dative preposition ki would be used.
Content 1: \gll Ko Koka te \ꞌīŋoa o tō\ꞌona hoi... ko Parasa \textbf{to} \textbf{te} \textbf{rū\ꞌau} era \ꞌā\ꞌana. | \gls PROM Koka ART name of POSS.3SG.O horse PROM Parasa ART:of ART old_woman DIST POSS.3SG.A | \glt ‘Koka was the name of the horse he went on, Parasa the (name) of his old wife.’
Content 2: \gll Te taŋata e ai rō \ꞌā tā\ꞌana kai, ka va\ꞌai \textbf{to} \textbf{te} \textbf{taŋata} \ꞌina \ꞌā\ꞌana kai. | \gls ART man IPFV exist EMPH CONT POSS.3SG.A food IMP give ART:of ART man NEG POSS.3SG.A food | \glt ‘The man who has food, should give some to the man who does not have food.’
Content 3: \gll Te ŋā kai \ꞌāpī ra\ꞌe era... e ma\ꞌu \textbf{to} \textbf{te} \textbf{hare} \textbf{pure} \ꞌi ra\ꞌe. | \gls ART PL food new first DIST IPFV carry ART:of ART house prayer at first | \glt ‘The first food... they first had to take some to the church (lit. carry those of the church)’

Knowledge Point: Semantically, (\ref{ex:6.23}–\ref{ex:6.24}) are similar to the partitive\is{Partitive} construction discussed above. In both cases, the noun phrase refers to something which is destined for the person referred to; moreover, the sense is partitive\is{Partitive}: ‘some of the food, some of the clothes’. Also, in both cases the to{}-phrase is independent: there is no head noun to which it is attached. The difference is that in the partitive\is{Partitive} construction in (\ref{ex:6.16}–\ref{ex:6.18}) above the possessee is expressed by a genitive phrase o te kahu which is semantically the head of the phrase (the noun phrase as a whole refers to ‘clothes’, not to ‘Vaha’), while in (\ref{ex:6.23}–\ref{ex:6.24}) it is not expressed at all.
Content 1: \gll Te taŋata e ai rō \ꞌā tā\ꞌana kai, ka va\ꞌai \textbf{to} \textbf{te} \textbf{taŋata} \ꞌina \ꞌā\ꞌana kai. | \gls ART man IPFV exist EMPH CONT POSS.3SG.A food IMP give ART:of ART man NEG POSS.3SG.A food | \glt ‘The man who has food, should give some to the man who does not have food.’
Content 2: \gll Te ŋā kai \ꞌāpī ra\ꞌe era... e ma\ꞌu \textbf{to} \textbf{te} \textbf{hare} \textbf{pure} \ꞌi ra\ꞌe. | \gls ART PL food new first DIST IPFV carry ART:of ART house prayer at first | \glt ‘The first food... they first had to take some to the church (lit. carry those of the church)’
Content 3: \gll Mai \textbf{tā\ꞌaku} \textbf{o} \textbf{te} \textbf{vai}. | \gls hither POSS.1SG.A of ART water | \glt ‘Give me some water.’
Content 4: \gll He ta\ꞌo tako\ꞌa \textbf{to} \textbf{rāua} \textbf{o} \textbf{te} \textbf{taŋata} mo kai. | \gls NTR cook_in_earth_oven also ART:of 3PL of ART man for eat | \glt ‘They also cooked people for them(selves) to eat.’
Content 5: \gll Te taŋata e ai rō \ꞌā tā\ꞌana kai, ka va\ꞌai \textbf{to} \textbf{te} \textbf{taŋata} \ꞌina \ꞌā\ꞌana kai. | \gls ART man IPFV exist EMPH CONT POSS.3SG.A food IMP give ART:of ART man NEG POSS.3SG.A food | \glt ‘The man who has food, should give some to the man who does not have food.’
Content 6: \gll Te ŋā kai \ꞌāpī ra\ꞌe era... e ma\ꞌu \textbf{to} \textbf{te} \textbf{hare} \textbf{pure} \ꞌi ra\ꞌe. | \gls ART PL food new first DIST IPFV carry ART:of ART house prayer at first | \glt ‘The first food... they first had to take some to the church (lit. carry those of the church)’

Knowledge Point: Possessive constructions occur not only as modifiers in the noun phrase, but in a range of other constructions as well. This section gives a concise listing; all of these constructions (with the exception of the elliptic construction in \REF{ex:6.34} below) are discussed in more detail elsewhere in this grammar.\footnote{\label{fn:287}Not included here are possessives expressing the subject of a relative clause in the “possessive-relative construction”; as argued in \sectref{sec:11.4.4}, these should be considered as normal noun-phrase possessors which are syntactically separate from the relative clause.}
Content 1: \gll He toe e toru te \ꞌaŋahuru nō toe, ku oti \ꞌā \textbf{to} \textbf{haho}. | \gls NTR remain NUM three ART ten just remain PRF finish CONT ART:of outside | \glt ‘Only thirty (men) were left, those outside were finished.’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{\ref{sec:6.2.3}.5} Possessives of the o{}-class may serve as the predicate of existential-locative clauses (\sectref{sec:9.3.2}); see \sectref{sec:6.3.1}.8 below on the locative use of possessives. In modern Rapa Nui, Ø-possessives are used as in \REF{ex:6.31}; in older Rapa Nui, t{}-possessives were used as in (\ref{ex:6.32}–\ref{ex:6.33}).
Content 1: \gll ¿E ai rō \ꞌā te ika \textbf{o} \textbf{roto}? | \gls ~IPFV exist EMPH CONT ART fish of inside | \glt ‘Are there fish inside (the net)?’
Content 2: \gll He taŋata \textbf{to} \textbf{nei}... Ŋata Vake te \ꞌīŋoa. | \gls PRED person ART:of PROX Ngata Vake ART name | \glt ‘There was a man here, called Ngata Vake.’
Content 3: \gll He taŋata \textbf{to} \textbf{ruŋa} to te motu, ko Motu Tapu te \ꞌīŋoa. | \gls PRED man ART:of above ART:of ART islet PROM Motu Tapu ART name | \glt ‘There was a man on the islet which was called Motu Tapu’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{\ref{sec:6.3.1}.8} The possessor may be a location to which the possessee belongs as in \REF{ex:6.44}, or a place where the possessee is located at a given time, as in (\ref{ex:6.45}–\ref{ex:6.46}).
Content 1: \gll Te me\ꞌe nei he heke, he \ꞌanimare e tahi \textbf{o} \textbf{rote} \textbf{vaikava}. | \gls ART thing PROX PRED octopus PRED animal NUM one of inside_the ocean | \glt ‘The octopus is an animal of (lit. of inside) the ocean.’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌIna he ika \textbf{o} \textbf{\ꞌApina}. | \gls NEG PROM fish of Apina | \glt ‘There are no fish at Apina.’
Content 3: \gll Ko Alfredo te me\ꞌe era \textbf{o} \textbf{mu\ꞌa} i te microfono. | \gls PROM Alfredo ART thing DIST of front at ART microphone | \glt ‘Alfredo is the one in front of the microphone.’

Knowledge Point: In (\ref{ex:6.45}–\ref{ex:6.46}), o is close in meaning to the locative \textit{{\ꞌ}i} ‘in, at’. As these examples show, the possessive is used especially in negative\is{Negation} or interrogative\is{Question} clauses. In those sentences, \textit{{\ꞌ}i}\is{i ‘in, at’@{\ꞌ}i ‘in, at’} is considered awkward.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌIna he ika \textbf{o} \textbf{\ꞌApina}. | \gls NEG PROM fish of Apina | \glt ‘There are no fish at Apina.’
Content 2: \gll Ko Alfredo te me\ꞌe era \textbf{o} \textbf{mu\ꞌa} i te microfono. | \gls PROM Alfredo ART thing DIST of front at ART microphone | \glt ‘Alfredo is the one in front of the microphone.’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{\ref{sec:6.3.1}.9} When the head noun expresses time, the possessive may express an event with respect to which this time applies. In \REF{ex:6.47} the event is punctual, and ‘three days’ is the time elapsed after the event. In \REF{ex:6.48} the event is durative\is{Aspect!durative}, and ‘eight days’ is the time elapsed since the beginning of this event. (In both cases, ka indicates that a certain moment in time has been reached, see \sectref{sec:4.3.2.2}.)
Content 1: \gll Ka toru mahana \textbf{o} \textbf{te} \textbf{tanu} o Kava, he \ꞌui e Puakiva ki a Pipi... | \gls CNTG three day of ART bury of Kava NTR ask AG Puakiva to PROP Pipi | \glt ‘Three days after (lit. of) the burial of Kava, Puakivi asked Pipi...’
Content 2: \gll Ka va\ꞌu mahana \textbf{o} \textbf{te} \textbf{noho} o Eugenio o te hāpī \ꞌi Vaihū... | \gls CNTG eight day of ART stay of Eugenio of ART teach at Vaihu | \glt ‘When he had stayed and taught for eight days in Vaihu...’

Knowledge Point: The possessive after the temporal noun may also refer to somebody or something which was involved in a certain event at the time specified. The event itself is expressed as a relative clause\is{Clause!relative} following this noun. \REF{ex:6.49} can be translated literally ‘Three days of the rain which fell’.
Content 1: \gll E toru mahana \textbf{o} \textbf{te} \textbf{\ꞌua} i hoa ai, ko reherehe atu \ꞌā te \ꞌō\ꞌone. | \gls NUM three day of ART rain PFV throw PVP PRF soft:RED away CONT ART soil | \glt ‘When it had been raining for three days, the ground was quite soft.’

Subsection: Possessive relations marked with a and o\label{sec:6.3.3
Knowledge Point: The possessee is food. This can be food grown, caught or otherwise obtained by the possessor\is{Possession} as in \REF{ex:6.76} and \REF{ex:6.77}, or food/drink consumed – or destined to be consumed – by the possessor\is{Possession} as in \REF{ex:6.78}.
Content 1: \gll He to\ꞌo i \textbf{tā\ꞌana} \textbf{kūmara} kerikeri era. | \gls NTR take ACC POSS.3SG.A sweet_potato dig:RED DIST | \glt ‘He took his sweet potato that he had dug up.’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌIna kai rava\ꞌa rahi \textbf{tā\ꞌana} \textbf{ika}. | \gls NEG NEG.PFV obtain much POSS.3SG.A fish | \glt ‘He did not catch much fish (lit. his fish)’
Content 3: \gll Ko hiko \ꞌā \textbf{tā\ꞌaku} \textbf{haraoa} e Te Manu. | \gls PRF snatch CONT POSS.1SG.A bread AG Te Manu | \glt ‘Te Manu has snatched away my bread.’

Subsection: Possessive relations marked with a and o\label{sec:6.3.3
Knowledge Point: Horses, however, are o{}-possessed, as they are animals of transport (see (\ref{ex:6.86}–\ref{ex:6.87}) in the next section).
Content 1: \gll He ha\ꞌamata he aŋa i \textbf{tō\ꞌona} \textbf{pē\ꞌue}. | \gls NTR begin NTR make ACC POSS.3SG.O mat | \glt ‘He began to make his mat.’
Content 2: \gll te pu\ꞌa e pu\ꞌa era \textbf{te} \textbf{rua} \textbf{o} \textbf{Eugenio} | \gls ART cover IPFV cover DIST ART hole of Eugenio | \glt ‘the lid that covered Eugenio’s grave’

Subsection: Possessive relations marked with a and o\label{sec:6.3.3
Knowledge Point: This means that fields and gardens can be either a- or o-possessed, depending on whether the focus is on possession (o) or labour (\textit{{\ꞌ}a}); cf. \REF{ex:6.75} in the previous section.
Content 1: \gll E hakaheu \ꞌana tū rū\ꞌau era i \textbf{tā\ꞌana} \textbf{kona} \textbf{\ꞌoka} \textbf{tiare}. | \gls IPFV weed CONT DEM old_woman DIST ACC POSS.3SG.A place plant flower | \glt ‘The old woman was weeding her flower garden.’

Subsection: Possessive relations marked with a and o\label{sec:6.3.3
Knowledge Point: The following pair of examples show the contrast between the action as such as in \REF{ex:6.109} and the product of an action as in \REF{ex:6.110}:
Content 1: \gll He riro he taŋata rivariva hai \textbf{\ꞌaiua} \textbf{o} \textbf{Eugenio}. | \gls NTR become PRED man good:RED INS help of Eugenio | \glt ‘He became a good man with Eugenio’s help.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Tā\ꞌana} \textbf{\ꞌaiua} he pua\ꞌa e tahi. | \gls POSS.3SG.A help PRED cow NUM one | \glt ‘His help/contribution (for the feast) was a cow.’

Subsection: Possessive relations marked with a and o\label{sec:6.3.3
Knowledge Point: Verbs expressing verbal utterances (‘say’, ‘tell’, ‘sing’) show the same distinction between the product of an action and the action itself. Utterances made by the possessor\is{Possession} – words, stories, songs, et cetera – are a{}-possessed, as in (\ref{ex:6.111}–\ref{ex:6.112}). On the other hand, when the act of uttering itself is in focus, the possessor\is{Possession} is o{}-marked, as in (\ref{ex:6.113}–\ref{ex:6.114}):
Content 1: \gll I oti era te \textbf{\ꞌa\ꞌamu} \textbf{\ꞌa} \textbf{\ꞌOrohe}... | \gls PFV finish DIST ART story of.A Orohe | \glt ‘When Orohe’s story was finished...’
Content 2: \gll He katikati i \textbf{tā\ꞌana} \textbf{hīmene} a Kava. | \gls NTR sing ACC POSS.3SG.A song PROP Kava | \glt ‘Kava sang his song.’
Content 3: \gll Nōatu \textbf{tō\ꞌona} \textbf{ture} mai. | \gls no_matter POSS.3SG.O scold hither | \glt ‘Don’t mind his scolding.’
Content 4: \gll Ko huru kē \ꞌā \ꞌo \textbf{tō\ꞌoku} \textbf{ta\ꞌe} \textbf{pāhono} i te vānaŋa \ꞌui mai. | \gls PRF manner different CONT because_of POSS.1SG.O CONNEG answer ACC ART word ask hither | \glt ‘\is{Verb!nominalised}He feels strange because I didn’t answer (lit. my not answering) his question.’
